content.description: Traverse the horizontal crack above the Cresent Cave. Â Climb up to lower horizontal crack and hand traverse left. Pumpy and good for laps and circuits. The upper horizontal crack is ok too and only 5.7.
content.location: The two horizontal cracks in the center of Washington Wall can be traversed on top rope.

content.description: Begin partway up on the block and climb a right-slanting crack about fifteen feet to a hollow-sounding flake.  Move left a few moves along a faint feature and finish up to a notch.
content.location: Western end of the Washington Wall on the boulder.

content.description: Just left of the "crescent cave," begin in a short, shallow, left-facing corner.  Climb the corner and right-slanting crack to a left-slanting crack.  Finish up past a green patch to easier rock.
content.location: Just to the left of the crescent cave.

content.description: Start from the block at the far-left side of the face.  Climb up the nose about 12 feet, then move right to a large bucket hold.  Finish on the last few moves of Pyrrhic Victory.
content.location: Start from the block at the far-left side of the face.

content.description: Power up left and right facing flakes to an overhang.  Move to the left and up to easier rock.
content.location: Start just to the right of crescent cave.

content.description: Climb the blocky crack located just left of the cliff break.  This crack can be dirty and overgrown at times.
content.protection: Small to medium cams will protect this climb or you can do it on top rope.  Top roping is more common.
content.location: It is located near the cliff break between the Washington Wall and the Main Wall.

content.description: Great crack.  Don't miss this one.
content.protection: Chains removed, sling tree for top rope or trad lead. The crack eats BD 0.75-4 cams, one or two small pieces (BD 0.3-0.5) adequately protect the face above the crack.
content.location: Climb the obvious crack on the left hand center of the wall.

content.description: Begin below a small A-shaped overhang.  Start up and thin seam on small, pocket-like openings, but after a few moves reach left to a good, left-facing edge.  Now climb difficult moves up past the A-shaped overhang, then follow much better holds to the top.
content.location: Ten feet to the right of Crescent Crack.

content.description: Great moves on nice rock.  Start about five feet left of a hand crack at an incipient seam.  Climb bouldery moves up the seam to a greenish rock, then fire straight up the face to a pine tree.

This slightly overhanging face contains some of the hardest routes at Crescent Rocks. It also contains the best 5.9 (Crescent Crack) at the crag. Close tree proximity make this a great spot for top roping, if you set up correctly you can climb more than one route without moving the anchors.
